note.p: Orson Hyde Crandall was a physician, Union soldier, and private secretary to a Mississippi governor during the Reconstruction era.

Born on March 31, 1827, in Cicero, New York, Crandall studied medicine at Cincinnati’s Eclectic School of Medicine and became a practicing physician in 1851. He moved to Illinois and volunteered for military service when the Civil War broke out in 1861. Crandall first enlisted in the Fifth Illinois Light Artillery before being appointed assistant surgeon of the Twenty-fourth Illinois Infantry Regiment. At the end of the war, Crandall served as a surgeon at a U.S. military post in Brookhaven, Mississippi. He remained there until being appointed private secretary to military governor Adelbert Ames in 1869. He returned to Illinois in 1870 and worked as a physician for several more years.

Crandall died on January 17, 1920. He was married twice, first to Emily Hitchcock, and later to Ruth Adelaide Patchin. He had at least two children. Crandall is buried in Woodland Cemetery in Quincy, Illinois.

(FindaGrave; “Crandall, Orson H.,” U.S. Civil War Pension Index: General Index to Pension Files, 1861-1934; Tri-Weekly Clarion, Meridian, MS, March 27, 1869; 1870 Federal Census, Woodstock, McHenry, Illinois, Roll M593_257, p. 295B)

Moses Hubbard Tuttle was a Union officer during the Civil War who became a public official in Mississippi during Reconstruction.

Born in 1839 in Massachusetts, Tuttle volunteered for military service after the Civil War broke out in 1861. He first served in the Forty-ninth Massachusetts Infantry Regiment, before being commissioned as an officer in the Fiftieth United States Colored Infantry Regiment, a regiment comprised of Black soldiers from Louisiana. Tuttle was promoted to lieutenant colonel and participated with the regiment in campaigns in the deep south. In particular, Tuttle was present at the Battle of Fort Blakeley in April 1865. After the Civil War, Tuttle remained in military service as part of the occupation force in Mississippi. He then separated from the army and accepted an appointment as sheriff in Carroll County, Mississippi, from Governor Adelbert Ames in 1869. He served in that capacity for several years, and then was elected to the Mississippi Senate in the mid-1870s.

Tuttle left Mississippi in the late nineteenth century and moved west. He died in 1911 in Washington state. He was married to Emma Teresa Taggart and had at least one child that lived to adulthood. Tuttle is buried in Sunset Memorial Park in Hoquiam, Washington.
(FindaGrave; Wikipedia; National Park Service; Fred M. Witty, “Reconstruction in Carroll and Montgomery Counties,” Publications of the Mississippi Historical Society, X, 118-119)
